stem: A 68-year-old client is on Day 4 following a large Anteroseptal MI. Based on the documentation in the Acute Ischemia & Mechanical Complication Log, which finding indicates the most likely complication?

tabs.title: New Clinical Assessment
tabs.content:
Situation: Sudden onset of dyspnea and hypotension.
Cardiac: New, loud holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border (LLSB). A palpable vibration (thrill) is felt in the same area.
Lungs: Bilateral crackles throughout all lobes.

tabs.title: Stat Bedside Echo
tabs.content: Impression: New defect in the interventricular septum with large left-to-right shunt. Normal valve function (no mitral regurgitation). Pulmonary artery pressures are significantly elevated.

rationale.correct: This is a **Ventricular Septal Rupture (VSR) (a1)**, a lethal mechanical complication occurring 3-5 days post-MI as the necrotic tissue softens. The hallmark cues are a **new holosystolic murmur** at the **left lower sternal border** with a **thrill**, and the echo confirmation of a **left-to-right shunt**. This causes sudden right-heart overload and cardiogenic shock. Mitral regurgitation (a2) from papillary rupture would have a similar murmur but would be heard at the *apex* and radiate to the axilla.
clinicalPearls: VSR = Hole in the septum. Murmur = LLSB.
Papillary Rupture = Mitral Regurgitation. Murmur = Apex/Axilla.
Both are surgical emergencies and cause rapid shock.
Treatment involves an Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) to reduce afterload and emergent surgery.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Free Wall Rupture (a3) because the client is in shock.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In Free Wall Rupture, the heart bleeds into the pericardium (Tamponade); you would see muffled heart sounds and JVD, but **NOT** a loud murmur. A loud murmur after an MI always means a 'Hole' (Septal) or a 'Flap' (Valve).
